[i]PEAK[/i] is a mountaineering, survival platformer. Balancing resources, helping one another in co-op, and taking risks to ascend up towards your goal is all part of the fun. There is a lot of artistry and effort put into this wonderful game with its straightforward objective to reach the top. While the game is designed with multiplayer in mind, it is also incredibly good even when trekking it alone.

The game is well crafted visually in its daily random map generation and character designs. Biomes have distinct aesthetics which come with their own unique set of hazards. They challenge players with different kinds of environmental obstacles -- including various fauna -- and weather conditions. The terrain for each biome never look out of place due to the excellent use of shadows and lighting, and objects and flora are seamlessly integrated into the environment. In addition, the sound design really lends itself to the tone and atmosphere of each biome in its ambience. The music, or lack thereof at times, also emphasizes the feelings of isolation (especially in solo expeditions) or the pressure to continually move upwards and onwards or face dire consequences. A lot of care was also put into characters as well with player characters having charming and expressive designs. Their colorful, cartoony look makes players easy to spot from the environment. The effort put into making visible responses for various player actions and gameplay movements make things feel more natural in co-op sessions. Mouths that move while using proximity chat and eyes that follow you when you're close are nice touches. The addition of emotes and the ability to point things out for everyone are appreciated.

As a survival platformer, the game can be unforgiving. You and your group's pathfinding skills will be put to the test as you ascend towards the peak. Whether going in alone with no others to rely on or as part of a group of friends (and setting aside any hijinks between players), balancing cautiousness and speed will be essential and you must use items and tools as efficiently as possible and take risks when necessary in order to proceed. The goal of reaching the summit can be a puzzle all on its own while minimizing injuries but there are also various ways how each biome can throw debuffs at you with its challenges such as hunger or poison. They will impede a player's stamina which makes climbing more difficult. In later difficulties the game not only makes climbing harder to do, but it also adds pressure on players with a long-term doom counter that forces players to race against time as well or die. Yes, dying sucks but the variety and ways players can overcome challenges keeps things interesting. In a group it's best to work together, share resources, and help each other by literally lending a helping hand to pull friends up. But if someone does die and have not yet been revived, then it's not the end for them. Dead players will return as ghosts to haunt your friends. Though ideally they'll help their living counterparts by pointing out the best routes or items. (Who packs a [i]cannon[/i] in their luggage anyway? On a side note though, I love how the game incorporates the tutorial by way of minigames and the player lobby seamlessly into the game's world. I also love how Steam achievements are directly tied to the badges on a player character's sash.) Thankfully, the game eases players into the world of [i]PEAK[/i] with smaller challenges before the bigger, do-or-die challenges found later. Players always start on the "Shore" after waking from the plane crash to get them rolling. Reaching the end of a biome allows players to recuperate a bit and revive any dead party members before pressing on until the players ultimately reach "The Kiln", the final area before the peak, which requires players to use all their honed skills and items to overcome.

[i]PEAK[/i] is an excellently designed game for both single player and multiplayer. The game makes players think about their pathfinding and how to use any found tools in the best possible way. The game can be difficult and can sometimes be frustrating, but when you or your group finally reach the peak there's always a sense of relief and joy. And always remember "Rule 0", my friends, [b]never abandon a friend in need.[/b]

TL;DR: Fun and colourful but sometimes frustrating coop game about climbing and finding your way through worlds that change daily. This review is written from a "pre-finished" viewpoint (at the time of this review, I haven't played through the whole game).

From Team PEAK and the publishers Aggro Crab and Landfall comes PEAK, a coop climbing/find your way game for up to four simulatenous players.

The premise of the game is that you and your fellow players board a plane and tragedy strikes. The plane crashes and you're stranded on some unknown island. Suddenly, you're fighting for your survival and trying to reach civilization once again.
Not only do you have to scale difficult terrain, you also have to find some food to keep going. The better you're fed, the more stamina you have to tackle your challenges. And on top of that - at least with the Roots update - you will also encounter enemy-type creatures that are out to get you. And then there's some additional "natural" obstacles and conditions like heavy wind which will hinder your progress, so you'll have to learn how to deal with that. Also... you can slip on some objects, so watch your step!

You have to get to know your surroundings, learn which plants might be safe to eat or which herb does help in certain situations. There's some help if you keep your eyes peeled: you can find some written tips to help you understand what's what. You can also find items that may help you on your way through the game - or some that might just be cluttering your inventory, depending on your playstyle. Think of ropes you can use to help your fellow players reach areas they might not be able to climb anymore because they are hurt or out of stamina. Or think of noisy little trumpets you can use to annoy your friends. "Ah, there's an inventory?" you might ask. Yes. But it is limited to three slots plus a backpack. And you have to search for those backpacks, since they're not too easy to come by.

The graphics are colourful, the player characters being depicted in a cartoonish style with some customisation options like diverse facial expressions or different clothing (some of which needs to be unlocked by playing the game). The areas you reach are kind of themed, starting you in a rocky beach area and encountering others like a huge mushroom forest (this came in with the roots update) or lava areas - among others. Each "biome" has its own difficulties and quirks you have to
manage.

I have to say the music seems relaxing most of the time and since the situations can get a bit tense that's very welcome. As I use to say: if the sounds don't feel out of place for you, they did a good job. And as of now I don't feel that the sound effects are misplaced at all. Also I didn't notice any "too loud/too silent"-type problems. Aaaaaand of course the game has microphone capabilities, so... just mute your discord if you want to use the in-game voice chat options. This is fun because sometimes you get lost or separated and can listen for the voices of your fellow players in the distance. Or listen to their screams when they plummet to their deaths.
Yes, there is a "death mechanic". Players who suffered heavy injuries will KO and be able to follow the other still alive players around and talk to them, so you're not completely out of the game. If your friends reach certain areas you can get revived and continue the stressful journey.

Earlier I wrote that the game can get "frustrating". Yeah, I've stood in front of some walls/mountains and asked myself: "How? How in the hell should this be possible?". And I'm not sure if every scenario is "doable", but that's kind of the design I guess.
You will fall. You will reach dead ends. There will be environmental hazards that will neutralize you at the worst timing possible. If you can live with that, you're fine.

At the time of this review, the devs still care for the game, putting out bug fixes and additions to the game. We all like that, don't we? For you achievement hunters: currently there are 54 steam achievements you can work towards and none of those seem too over the top, although a lot of them are circumstancial.

The friends I'm playing with and me still have to finish the game, so I don't know everything yet. There's still a lot for us to find out about the game so I guess this review isn't too "spoilery".

Thanks for reading,
Ossel

PS: I might edit this review if there should be any questions or if I should feel like I forgot to mention something.

Peak is a masterclass in combining punishing cooperative survival with slapstick comedy. This physics-based climbing game puts you in the boots of a stranded nature scout who must scale a procedurally generated mountain or die trying. And dying is very much part of the experience.

The Climb That Breaks Friendships
The game's greatest strength lies in its commitment to both calculated strategy and chaotic mishaps. You'll find yourself ascending hostile terrain with up to three other players, ostensibly working together to reach the summit and call for rescue. The cartoonish physics, proximity voice chat, and deliberately punishing stamina system create a brilliant framework for emergent comedy that never feels forced.

The survival mechanics are deliciously challenging, requiring genuine teamwork and constant risk assessment. Whether you're gambling on poisonous mushrooms for stamina buffs, managing your limited inventory of climbing gear, or trying to revive a teammate who slipped on a jellyfish, every decision feels like a high-stakes gamble. The friendly sabotage opportunities add both tension and hilarious moments of accidental (or intentional) betrayal, perfectly fitting the game's slapstick tone.

Daily Disasters
What sets Peak apart is how its procedurally generated mountain resets every 24 hours, ensuring no two climbs feel identical. From the rocky Shore to the hazard-rich Tropics, through the frostbitten Alpine zones to the volatile Caldera and finally the molten Kiln, each biome introduces fresh challenges while maintaining the game's brilliantly absurd tone.

The progression system keeps you engaged through a badge collection system and the intrinsic motivation of mastering increasingly difficult terrain. Each new piece of equipment‚Äîropes, climbing spikes, pitons‚Äîopens up tactical possibilities, though the limited inventory forces brutal choices that keep gameplay tense even after many hours.

Highlights
Exceptional cooperative gameplay that rewards coordination
Brilliant physics-based comedy and emergent moments
Challenging stamina management and risk-reward decisions
Daily mountain variations keeping content fresh
Outstanding slapstick physics and cartoon-like movement
Proximity voice chat enhancing sound immersion

Minor Drawbacks
Technical bugs and lag can occasionally ruin runs
Can be punishingly difficult for solo players
Limited content variety after extended play sessions

TL;DR: The Tropics were tough, but manageable and learnable. Roots is downright cruel and unforgiving and doesn't give players, especially new ones, the chance to learn anything without being completely overwhelmed. I can't really recommend this game anymore since it's has such a high skill ceiling now.

Long Review:
For context, the Tropics give you 6 hazards to deal with: exploding clumps, poisonous clumps, poisonous plants (bushes and thorns), rain, waterfalls (but they were never really in the way imo) and lava (which was never really a threat, tbh). The Tropics were tough, but not impossible. You had to survey your climb, plan things out with companions, and strategically work through winding paths and be willing to risk back-tracking to find better options. Rain was annoying but never actively hurt you. Waterfalls and lava never obscured paths. The clumps were big hazards but were avoidable. The change in difficulty from Shoreline to the Tropics was tough, but doable after you started learning what to look out for.

Roots, on the other hand, is almost impossible to beat in its current state. You have the same exploding clumps as before, spore clumps that do the same amount of damage as poison but linger much longer, CLOUDS of spores that BLOCK routes to the actual climb, wind that actively tosses players around EVEN IF you're hiding from it behind rocks, trees, or INSIDE CAVES (the caves lead nowhere more often than not, by the way), spiders that linger and catch you, bugs that follow you and toss you around, waterfalls that actually block viable routes ON THE GROUND, and ZOMBIES THAT CAN CLIMB AND FOLLOW YOU AROUND for Christ's sake. That's 8 hazards, by the way (2 that actively obstruct your exploration and **3** that actively pursue you and endanger you if you are within earshot).

It would be one thing if new to only semi-experienced players like me had issues. But I'm seeing friends and reviewers who have 50-100+ hours in the game struggle and clearly have a hard time. It'd be one thing if this was all balanced with all the food around in Roots, but new mushrooms give you spores and lower your stamina for a significant amount of time, making it harder to brace for the wind, run from zombies and climb. It'd be one thing if zombies only spawned in ascension difficulties and/or could only follow you on the ground, but they spawn at ALL difficulties, CAN CLIMB, FOLLOW YOU, LUNGE AT YOU, AND CAN INFECT YOUR FRIENDS TO ADD EVEN MORE THREATS TO THIS MAP. With all of that happening and ruining climbs, how could anyone learn what to do in this map, let alone be encouraged to?

i've seen plenty of insightful reviews for this game, positive and negative. since it's unrelated, i won't divulge my full thought on what others make of this game, but i will talk about experiences of my own and those i know. 

as with many games, opinionated criticisms related to quality are in abundance. we have bugs that are discovered with the game's development over time, inconsistencies between biomes, accessibility issues, and other problems people have with the game's functionality... a large fraction of what i listed, while not entirely unreasonable to address, are liable to change with enough collective userbase complaint. 

as someone with a steam deck, a more unavoidable issue is the fact this game is near inoperable on any device with specs that aren't remarkably high-end. 
from what i've seen, the divide this can create is almost oppressive. i say this because i've experienced many people (including my own friends) have the complaint of "i bought this game, but i can't run it" only to gain the response of "what are *your* specs? why don't *you* get a better graphics build and adapt?" if a game is meant to be enjoyed on a large multiplayer scope, i think that's a redundant argument. 
i also don't appreciate that this game lacks lan support. planned obsolescence for this game in particular seems to be a misplaced decision by the peak team, especially as landfall/aggrocrab as companies seem to understand how it feels to make a game with passion, or at least *for* people to be passionate about playing. 

if games like peak are intended by the devs to be enjoyed, i would *hope* that attention breached the longevity of whatever "live service" marketing seems to be going on with peak at the moment. 

mechanically, peak is one of *the most* fun games i've played in years. this is the main reason it's earning game reward nominations after having only released half a year ago. however, i think it's shallow to overlook the glaring problems caused by the companies' attempt to expand on a quick opportunity since the game has succeeded so quickly. it's only my specific circumstance (my specific device and internet plan) that allow me to enjoy this game in its full scope. while many others are equally as fortunate, several more unfortunately aren't. it creates the sort of atmosphere that is (from personal experience) reminiscent to this: those who are continuously able to play nintendo games, paying for their services, being fully aware they'll become null in the future- vs. those who cannot afford it, and still have to watch as the perpetuation of this kind of system rooted by economic growth in gaming industries tends to cycle. 
while i enjoy playing the game, it's difficult to recommend to most, so overall i can't pass the blue thumb in good conscience. there are plenty other multiplayer games with excellent mechanics, designs, and worldbuilding that are more user-accessible, as well as *less* costly to begin with. 
i do have some hope for the circumstance of this game, but i can honestly see its future going either way-- lasting, if its developers fully listen to their community, or fizzling out as if it were some other aaa game designed to move on from. as it stands now, this game is purely beneficial for those who can afford it. it's unfortunate how many users have already wound up disappointed with the results of such a thought-out game.
